comments.commentBody: This doesn't give us much to look forward to. I wish more women would become congress members!

I asked this question of the Reagan transition in 1981.  That is when action was needed to save the financial system.  Now it's too late, and the shots are still being called by the lawyers for the banksters.

Dolph,

It's not a question of whether the candidate has a net positive favorability... it's whether the favorability ratings are higher or lower than the opponent.

That is the question that Nate was attempting to answer. In this case, Obama's numbers aren't stellar, but they are clearly better than Romney's... so Nate was asking whether that fact has any predictive value.

I believe that it does.

Approval ratings are way too simple a statistic to be a good predictor.  I strongly disapprove of Obama's spineless performance as President and his basing every single decision on politics rather than principle -- but I'll vote for him in November.   This will be an election of lesser of evils and that is clearly Obama, if for no other reason than the Supreme Court appointments that would be a disaster under Romney.

Good for  her!  I thoroughly disapprove of females selling their bodies to males who use them like objects rather than human beings, but since that's the way things work in Colombia, she was absolutely right in demanding full payment.  The cheapskate who hired her to service him (hey, is this guy married?  I hope his wife knocks sense into him before she leaves him) sounds like a real jerk; we can only hope he didn't make her pregnant with his DNA.  I thank her for helping expose this shabby situation, and I suggest the Secret Service hire her at the pay grade of her John, which would get her off the street; she can be a guest worker.

What is this...your editorial staff just thinks they can throw up any picture to go with a story?!  It is ridiculous that you have two black women in the background to go with your story or get your point across..It is offensive New York Times and racist ...I demand you change that picture immediately.  For those that are geographically illiterate your depiction would persuade that these women were black women.  This is Columbia!!!!! These people were Latino women what the heck is wrong with you? Black women do not live in Columbia...fix this picture immedately..your picture violates your comments rules as it is abusive!

I feel sorry for the families and co-workers of these men who
now have to listen and be embarrassed by their nonsensical explanations. These grown men all need a good smack!

Not only is this generally reprehensible behavior, the solicitation of a prostitute in any country, whether or not it is legal in that nation, by an American citizen, is a crime. This is part of how the USG fights trafficking in persons throughout the world, which is largely driven by prostitution. It is a crime for anyone. For military members it is a crime punishable by the UCMJ and a civil offense. Probably the same for the Secret Service.

Yes, this happens all the time and it's common knowledge that it does. It may shock the conscience of some, but for those who have been around a bit, it's less than a surprise. That doesn't make it right. Same thing with the pictures of US Soldiers with dead Afghan bomb makers. Wrong, illegal, shocks the conscience of some, but common knowledge that it happens all the time.
"President Obama is gearing up for his presidential campaign. He's creating a new series of ads. The first ad boasts 'just last week my Secret Service created jobs for 11 Colombian women.'"

Hmmm - I don't think you have any idea of life in Colombia if you think one needs to make $800 per night just to pay rent, or if you think Colombian escorts, even high end ones, typically charge $800, or do not engage in scams to get prices not agreed upon from those considered rich.  Yes, you are American, and have no  idea about life in Colombia.  I have no sympathy for the incompetent and overpaid agent, but lets not pretend the escort was some innocent victim either.

People, for those of you who have not been to college: It's Colombia, not Columbia (with a "u"). Second, prostitution IS NOT legal in Colombia. However, it is not enforced, meaning that if you chose to be a prostitute, it is unlikely anyone will stop you. I am a Colombian native who moved to the States during my teens and I consider myself an American. It is not uncommon for women to act as "escorts", not only in Colombia but anywhere else in the world, including NY where women sleep with men in exchange for Fendi bags and Jimmy Choo. Third, if you are seeking prostitution services ANYWHERE, you have to be aware of the risks, which include and are not limited to being beaten to death, robbed or in the best case, just ripped off. Eight-hundred dollars is not unreasonable for a Colombian escort to ask for.
These men are inexperienced buffoons, which have to pay for sex and couldn't handle a simple transaction. Colombians are decent people, these girls were just trying to make rent. Personally, I think is much demeaning to sleep with random men without any promises for free; which is what every single girl in this city has done at some point.

I guess what I find most troubling is that these people were there to protect our president in a country known for well armed drug lords, etc. and they're getting drunk and not getting sufficient rest (e.g. sleep) the night before.

If you're tired and hungover how good a job are you going to do protecting our president?

A lousy job, that's what.

Obviously, they fell down on the job....doubt this behavior is anything new and probably standard issue for government workers when out of the country, OK, I got it. I also think you can conclude that the agent, who created this mess, by only wanting to pay a fraction of the cost owed to a Latina was a racist to boot. I know if I was a black president, I would not want to depend on my life, that a guy with those attitudes was going to have my back.

We're given a rather detailed and titillating description of what the woman was wearing in the interview with the reporter, yet "the man who helps her find customers"--read, pimp--comes off like a talent agent. Thank you Renn Callahan for pointing out the hypocrisy of attitudes.

This is a total non-issue. The hand-wringing about security breaches or other stuff is just cover for the fact that some people love an excuse to name and shame, while pretending that they've never enjoyed a sexual act. The Germans call it Schadenfreude, we call it The New York Times.

Whether or not it's an all male or mixed gender secrete service staff, weren't these officers briefed or warned not to go crazy with alcohol fully knowing that it will diminish their capacity to respond to immediate threat or crisis. Yeah, sure, it's OK to mingle with the crowd, warm up with the locals but then how about scoping out potential threats or dangers while they're at it. They have 24 hours or so to clear the path before the boss arrives, right?  Good times, yey!

I am sure the agents in question know that they have let their service, country, families and themselves down.
However, I am surprised that they could somehow define themselves as being off duty? (I assume that was the case). I would say that you are not off duty at any time if you are in Secret Service, on a job abroad.

Let's hope that th politicians leave this to unfold as a typical situation that both men and woman traveling alone tend to bring-on themselves, and then regret it afterward.
Let's nor make this into another Election Year Political Football.

And, the assumption that the agents at the bar had two different views as to whether the women were prostitutes would be a very common one. Assuming the women are better than average looking, some men away from home don't try to Profile women, just get them into bed. Others, by the very nature of their jobs do so. I wonder if the ones who engaged in sex Profiled them, or not.

Poverty and inequality was one of the many topics treated in the international summit meeting... i think that sexual turism is part of that, and behind of that scandal there are women that are being treated as objects .Maybe this is another topic without response, I think that is not just a matter about the image of an institution but a chance to think the place of the women in politics, in education and in real actions.
How to contribute to Colombia to diminish the sexual turism?, Answer that question would be a good start point to help us in facing poverty and inequality.

Agreed, this incident was shameful, stupid, and inappropriate on the part of the agents involved. Public inebriation is bad enough; to cap it with indiscreet sexual activity is humiliating to the agents, the Service, and the nation. Secty Panetta got it right: these guys let down the boss, and in their line of work, that cannot be tolerated.

BUT--enough already. It happened, appropriate follow-up investigations and actions are in process, and it's time to move on. Thankfully, the subject article was not blazoned across the front page of the NYT. But I expect that it will continue to be an item of interest on cable news, in tabloids, and for the TV comics for days to come--till it's bumped by another naughty incident.

It's not that the nation is so Puritanical (altho certainly, evidence of those attitudes does persist). It's just that we seem compelled to wallow in and leer at the salacious, off-color suggestiveness of these recurrent stories.

To wit: Weiner, Cain, Spitzer, JFK, WJClinton, Dominique Straus-Kahn, etc; Santorum's social platform, States requiring medically unnecessary, invasive ultrasound as a condition for getting an abortion, attacks on American women's rights to decent healthcare that includes access to abortion and contraceptives, etc.

The hub-bub disguises and trivializes the underlying significance of this kind of event: each one illustrates disrespectful behavior towards and victimization of women.

Will it ever end?
Arguing with prostitutes?  It's the beggining of the end.  Are their excuses going to be, "the ladies in waiting" needed top security?  I can imagine their homecoming with their wives!
These were women just trying to collect Times subscrition money

@Hans Schmitt, who wrote, "In CRUSADE IN EUROPE by Dwight D Eisenhower, I recall reading a specific discussion of setting up an "officers; brothel"

Just in case you had any doubts."

You misremembered. I checked the book's index, then did a keyword search of the book in Google Books, just in case, and there's nothing in it about brothels, for officers or anyone else.

I had doubts, you see. For good reason.

Here is my suggestion. Fire the married agents for cheating on their wives. Warn the single ones about AIDS and Syphilis. Probably the agents were inspired by former bosses such as Presidents Roosevelt, JFK and Clinton. Its all very understandable.

Doesn't anyone have a problem with a 3rd world pro demanding $800? The $30 was likely the agreed price. She just decided that if she made a scene she might get more, and she did.

I doubt if she will ever work that area again! She had probably pulled this stunt successfully before but did not realize who the men were.

As for the travel schedule, do you really think it would just be laying around for anyone to see? Get real!

Do you think these men are on duty 24 hours a day? They did their jobs during the day. Did you expect them to sit at attention in their rooms at night.

Prostitution is legal there, they broke no law.

I know Cartagena quite well. I also know and have lived in most of the cities of Colombia, an extraordinary and wonderful country. Unlike other cities in Colombia, it is a tourist city at the beach with many European and some Canadian and US men. Men staying at the El Caribe Hotel (the agent's hotel) are presumed to be very wealthy, especially if they are not wearing blue jeans like all other men in Colombia except Bogotá. All the girls there work for the Colombian mafia. They will not be allowed into any clubs where they can meet tourists unless they pay what is basically a pimp. Competition is severe between the girls. They would be afraid to go in any club without their pimp's protection. The other girls will kill or beat them until no guy would want to look at them. Colombia has no food stamps or welfare system. The girls usually have a child and a mother they are supporting. When they leave a club with a guy, they owe their pimp an agreed amount, and they keep the rest.

When this Secret Service agent would not pay the girl, he was very likely taking the food out of her family's mouths and putting her at risk of getting killed or beat to hell by the pimp. That is why she was crying and became hysterical. Prostitution is a legal business (pimping is not) in Colombia. Of course, the police are concerned that she is not getting paid for her labor.
Too bad Clinton is not still the President. I do not think he would be the least but embarrassed.
